I don t know how iPython works but the export of SVG from DiagrammeR requires a special version using V8 (https://github.com/rich-iannone/DiagrammeR/pull/79)

However, after email from R core team member, the support of V8 has been removed because it is hard to install/maintain/test on Cran server (we received an email too for XGBoost project which uses DiagrammeR).

Some background: https://github.com/rich-iannone/DiagrammeR/issues/137

Kind regards,

The `mx.metric.np` function takes a numpy function as the first argument which is of the form `callable(label, pred)`. It returns an `EvalMetric` object that should be passed to `model.fit` function with `eval_metric` argument.

See [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/metric.py#L94) and [here](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py#L685) for more details.
should be faster since it's multithreaded. especially on ssd
In which case will this matter?
@tqchen Could you help on this?
It will not pose a problem, the requirement is that the data is copied out as soon as function finishes, and these temp variables are thread local

c.f. http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput
This page contains all the symbolic operators, maybe we should put the reference to ops to a more clear place

@yib2 Can you share the function you used?

One step toward this is to support typed NDArray, and then we can add a typecast operator, and gradually add fp16 and fixed point support, things should not be hard as mshadow is templatized, and we don't have to re-implement most of the code

1,2 are actually bugs. I just fixed them. Monitors are injected in between inplace ops so that we can get all intermediary results.

3 is because we we don't backprop to label. So ignoring it should be fine.

After better search:
https://github.com/rich-iannone/DiagrammeRsvg !!!

mx.metric.mlogloss <- mx.metric.custom("mlogloss", function(label, pred){

  label <- as.factor(label)
  label_mat <- matrix(0, nrow = length(label), ncol = length(levels(label)))
  sample_levels <- as.integer(label)
  for (i in 1:length(label)) label_mat[i, sample_levels[i]] <- 1
  label <- label_mat
  #I tried to multiply label sparse matrix with prediction matrix, but it returned an error, like feval() something. 

  label <- as.vector(t(label))
  eps <- 1e-15
  n <- nrow(pred)
  pred <- pmax(pmin(pred, 1 - eps), eps)
  MultiLogLoss <- (-1/n) \* sum(label \* log(pred))
  return(MultiLogLoss)
})

This is basically from package MLmetrics. It works well for mnist example, but the mlogloss may change while tuning the batch size. I think It only calculates a small proportion of data.
@yib2  It will be appreciated if you can also provide the code caused errors.

@thirdwing 

setwd('/Users/yib2/Documents/Graduate/Kaggle/Digit_Recognizer')
require(mxnet)

mx.metric.mlogloss <- mx.metric.custom("mlogloss", function(label, pred){
  label <- as.factor(label)
  label_mat <- matrix(0, nrow = length(label), ncol = length(levels(label)))
  sample_levels <- as.integer(label)
  for (i in 1:length(label)) label_mat[i, sample_levels[i]] <- 1
  label <- label_mat

  label <- as.vector(t(label))
  eps <- 1e-15
  n <- nrow(pred)
  pred <- pmax(pmin(pred, 1 - eps), eps)
  MultiLogLoss <- (-1/n) \* sum(label \* log(pred))
  return(MultiLogLoss)
})

train <- read.csv('train.csv', header=TRUE)
test <- read.csv('test.csv', header=TRUE)
train <- data.matrix(train)
test <- data.matrix(test)

train.x <- train[,-1]
train.y <- train[,1]

train.x <- t(train.x/255)
test <- t(test/255)

data <- mx.symbol.Variable("data")
fc1 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data, name="fc1", num_hidden=128)
act1 <- mx.symbol.Activation(fc1, name="relu1", act_type="tanh")
fc2 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(act1, name="fc2", num_hidden=64)
act2 <- mx.symbol.Activation(fc2, name="relu2", act_type="tanh")
fc3 <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(act2, name="fc3", num_hidden=10)
softmax <- mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(fc3, name="sm")

devices <- mx.cpu()
mx.set.seed(0)
model <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(softmax, X=train.x, y=train.y,
                                     ctx=devices, num.round=100, array.batch.size=100,
                                     learning.rate=0.07, momentum=0.9,  eval.metric=mx.metric.accuracy,
                                     initializer=mx.init.uniform(0.07),
                                     epoch.end.callback=mx.callback.log.train.metric(100))

Error in feval(as.array(label), as.array(pred)) :    dims [product 1000] do not match the length of object [2700]
When I used it on mnist example, it worked well. But this error raised when I used it on my project.

So do you mind sharing the data?

Without the data to reproduce the error, I can only guess the error is from 

``` r
label <- as.vector(t(label))
```

or

```
MultiLogLoss <- (-1/n) * sum(label * log(pred))
```

My data is big. You can change the array.batch.size in minst example, and you will see the length of label and pred is changing, so as for mlogloss itself. 

you may add a line: print(length(label)) to see how it happened.
submitted to arixv last night, will appear soon

Hi,

Thank you for your question. For CPU, you could not specify the device id. The device id is only used for GPU. MXNet uses multi-threaded engine to utilize the multi-core power. You could set `MXNET_CPU_WORKER_NTHREADS` environment variable to specify how many threads (roughly how many cores) you would like to use.

I think I know what you mean here and I just want to double check with your data.

In 

``` r
label_mat <- matrix(0, nrow = length(label), ncol = length(levels(label)))
```

You have made an assumption that `label` has labels for all classes, which is wrong when `array.batch.size` is small.

Yes. You got it. For a specific problem, I think i can fix it by setting the number of columns, but it is not suitable for general environment. That would be great if you add a new eval_metric in mxnet.
Thanks.

You can use the line below for now.

``` r
label_mat <- matrix(0, nrow = length(label), ncol = length(pred) / length(label) )
```
I am not sure about the exact details. One way I could think about is using a fixed-size inputs and a mask matrix that mask out those invalid input during training. This is what we did for LSTM.

@jermainewang Many thanks! Btw do I need to adjust `MXNET_CPU_PRIORITY_NTHREADS` (default 4) accordingly (for cpu-only mode)? Couldn't understand what "prioritized CPU jobs" means. Also any thoughts on my first two questions?

Thanks for the answer! I see two problems with this approach. For my use case during test phase I don't know max dimensions of my inputs ahead of time. The second problem is that the net will be doing unnecessary computations (it is especially bad if the size difference between an average input and the max is substantial). I think in Caffe this is solved by allowing tensors to be resized on demand. The resize operation will trigger memory allocation only if the new size is larger than the current, otherwise the existing allocation is not touched.
Normally you do  not have to. On CPU, most time consuming part are matrix multiplications, which is parallelized already if you use libraries such as openblas.

Hi, currently we don't have attention LSTM yet. I would say put the computation of score out of the LSTM cell but maybe you could find some more efficient way to implement them together. In terms of detailed implementation, could you represent the attention weight using a tensor?
This is something @antinucleon is looking at, we will need some internal softmaxTransform operator
@baoqingping did you figure out the fix?
You are right. That's why we are working on the minpy project that could do this dynamic things like [autograd](https://github.com/HIPS/autograd). We are working that so please stay tuned.
Hi, thank you for your contribution! It's not that "minor" at all :). Have put your name on the contributor list.

Seems the usage of `LinearRegressionOutput` and `LogisticRegressionOutput` is not clearly documented. Some math about the exact operation will be helpful. 

In my understanding, '...Output' are designed to be the output layers of the network, and behave differently at training and predicting. E.g. for `SoftmaxOutput`:
- At training: first softmax, and then a cross-entropy loss function attached automatically
- At predicting: softmax only, outputs values in [0,1]

We see here `SoftmaxOut` is doing softmax as the name suggested, but `LinearRegressionOut` seems do nothing other than the attached L2 loss at the training time of `model.FeedForward`: 

``` python
data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
label = mx.symbol.Variable('gt_label')
lr = mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(data=data,label=label,name='lr')
c_exec=lr.bind(ctx=mx.cpu(),args={'data':mx.nd.ones((2,3)),'gt_label':mx.nd.ones((2,3))})
c_exec.forward()
c_exec.outputs[0].asnumpy() # --> array([[ 1., 1., 1.], [ 1., 1., 1.]], dtype=float32)
lr.list_arguments()         # --> ['data', 'gt_label']
```

Some would expect from the name that `LinearRegressionOutput` will insert a linear regression operation (essentially a fully-connected layer), but there isn't. 

Similarly, `LogisticRegressionOutput` is only adding a logistic function 1/(1+exp(-x)): 

``` python
lr = mx.symbol.LogisticRegressionOutput(data=data,label=label,name='lr')
c_exec=lr.bind(ctx=mx.cpu(),args={'data':mx.nd.ones((2,3)),'gt_label':mx.nd.ones((2,3))})
c_exec.forward()
c_exec.outputs[0].asnumpy() # --> array([[ 0.7310586, 0.7310586, 0.7310586], [ 0.7310586, 0.7310586, 0.7310586]], dtype=float32)
lr.list_arguments()         # --> ['data', 'gt_label']
```

Please correct me if I get anything wrong. Also, what's the loss function used for `LogisticRegressionOutput`? Cross-entropy loss still `sum_i ( - y_i*log(o_i) - (1-y_i)*log(1-o_i))`?

What was wanted here was a dynamically resizable structure with fixed graph, this could possibly be done in the symbolic API as well, like what you  mentioned. 

The most flexible way will be imperative gradient @jermainewang  mentioned and that is most flexible direction the project can go
@tqchen Thanks! Any comments on my first two questions?

Corresponding keyword of symbol: softmax_label
Shape inconsistent, Provided =(100, 1), inferred shape=(100)

as you can see the model want's (100) and your label's shape is (100,1).
just do label=label.squeeze() and you should be good.

@pluskid that would be nice. I am trying to replicate the basic scalar multiplication tutorial from Theano ([https://github.com/Newmu/Theano-Tutorials/blob/master/0_multiply.py](https://github.com/Newmu/Theano-Tutorials/blob/master/0_multiply.py)) and TensorFlow ([https://github.com/nlintz/TensorFlow-Tutorials/blob/master/0_multiply.py](https://github.com/nlintz/TensorFlow-Tutorials/blob/master/0_multiply.py)) in MXNet. This works:

``` python
import mxnet as mx

A = mx.sym.Variable('A')
B = mx.sym.Variable('B')

Y = A * B

multiply = Y.bind(ctx=mx.cpu(), args={'A': mx.nd.ones(1) * 1, 'B': mx.nd.ones(1) * 2})

multiply.forward()

print multiply.outputs[0].asscalar() #2

multiply = Y.bind(ctx=mx.cpu(), args={'A': mx.nd.ones(1) * 3, 'B': mx.nd.ones(1) * 3})

multiply.forward()

print multiply.outputs[0].asscalar() #9
```

The CHN part in the URL is confusing:
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/doc/overview_chn.md 

CHN is a country code per ISO 3166-1[1]. I think you meant Chinese, as a language. In this case, "zh" should a proper language code as stated in ISO-639 [2].

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_3166-1_alpha-3
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_language
It's usually much faster to use numpy's own serialization than pickle.
The data is stored in a dictionary instead of a simple numpy array. And the data loading is asynchronously, it should be fine.

You can use batch callback to get it out, eg
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/callback.py#L30
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py#L199

pickle can be really slow on large nparrays and it sometimes take up several times more disk space. 

Also I think we should refactor the dataiterators to separate iterator and data source. One iterator should be able to provide data from many data source times as long as they have a common interface.

Please use `LeakyReLU` instead of `Activation`

I don't know what is your meaning. For example, gram matrix in neural art style, we can calculate gram of convolution feature in this way

```
def StyleGramExecutor(input_shape, ctx):
    # symbol
    data = mx.sym.Variable("conv")
    rs_data = mx.sym.Reshape(data=data, target_shape=(int(input_shape[1]), int(np.prod(input_shape[2:]))))
    weight = mx.sym.Variable("weight")
    rs_weight = mx.sym.Reshape(data=weight, target_shape=(int(input_shape[1]), int(np.prod(input_shape[2:]))))
    fc = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=rs_data, weight=rs_weight, no_bias=True, num_hidden=input_shape[1])
    # executor
    conv = mx.nd.zeros(input_shape, ctx=ctx)
    grad = mx.nd.zeros(input_shape, ctx=ctx)
    args = {"conv" : conv, "weight" : conv}
    grad = {"conv" : grad}
    reqs = {"conv" : "write", "weight" : "null"}
    executor = fc.bind(ctx=ctx, args=args, args_grad=grad, grad_req=reqs)
    return Executor(executor=executor, data=conv, data_grad=grad["conv"])
```

What's your expectation?
